Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research/LTREB Renewal: Successional Pathways and Rates of Change in Tropical Forests of Brazil, Costa Rica and Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a long-term project to study regeneration in tropical forests. The neoSelvas project unites six independently developed studies in a coordinated effort to understand and predict vegetation change during regeneration of tropical forests following pasture abandonment or shifting cultivation in Central and South America. It compares temporal variation in forest structure and species composition within plots with spatial variation observed among plots of different ages (a chronosequence). Over the coming five years, annual inventory data will be used to calculate rates of recruitment and mortality of tree and shrub species in different stages of regeneration and to characterize changes in the functional characteristics of tree species across plots and study areas and over time. At the end of this project, the accumulated data will provide a deeper understanding of the factors affecting species colonization, dispersal, functional trait distributions, and community assembly during succession.

Project results will provide new insights into mechanisms of regeneration in tropical forests. Datasets from the project supply essential information to guide forest restoration, carbon storage, and biodiversity conservation, and to enhance ecosystem modeling and global change predictions. These are all topics of direct societal relevance. Study plots provide collaborative opportunities for over 30 undergraduate, masters, doctoral, and postdoctoral researchers from Brazil, Costa Rica, US, Mexico, and The Netherlands.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our long-term research of tropical forest regrowth in Costa Rica, Mexico, and Brazil compared changes over time within individual study plots with patterns observed using single time measurements for plots of different age. Our results show strong effects of plot location on temporal changes in stem density, richness of tree species, and tree basal area within each region, emphasizing the importance of local soil and landscape factors and chance events that affect seed dispersal and tree species establishment. We also found predictable successional trends across all of our study areas that demonstrate how species traits, life histories, and ecological specialization of trees interact to influence tree species replacement, accumulation of biomass aboveground, and changes in tree species composition during forest regrowth.

Overall, our results show that it is possible to use single-time measurements from plots of different age to predict successional changes in species richness and biomass accumulation, but variability around this prediction is high and results from space-for-time substitutions can be misleading if sites are poorly replicated and are not representative of the area. Whereas 70% recovery of species richness and forest biomass can occur within 60-70 years on average, changes in tree species composition occur far more slowly and can take several centuries. Forests derived from former pasture or crop fields have similar rates of recovery when compared across Latin America, but within study regions the effects of former land use are significant. In Central Amazonia, pathways of forest succession follow different patterns for many years after pasture abandonment compared to shifting cultivation, and multiple cycles of crop cultivation can strongly limit recovery.

But long-term annual measurements offer critical insights into the mechanisms of successional change that cannot be provided by single-time studies, including assessments of tree growth, mortality, and recruitment. Rates of tree growth are initially very high during the first 10-15 years of forest regrowth, but tree mortality rates are also high, particularly in wetter regions. So high rates of biomass accumulation and carbon storage as the forest is established begin to decline due to increased rates of tree mortality and lower growth rates. During the first 25 years of forest succession rates of aboveground biomass accumulation are higher in wet vs. dry tropical forests, with higher rates of tree mortality in early stages in wetter forests.

In moist and wet forests of Costa Rica, Mexico, and Brazil, shade-intolerant trees that are common in early stages have functional characteristics of leaves and wood that favor rapid growth but low rates of persistence. Over time, these trees species are replaced by shade-tolerant species with higher wood density and tougher leaves, but slower growth rates. These functional changes are reversed in dry tropical forests, where early establishing species also require dense wood to tolerate low water availability. During the first three decades of forest regrowth, legume species (Pea family) are twice as abundant in dry compared to wet forests.

Our studies also revealed that tree species in wetter forests have greater specializations for early vs. late stage forest than species in dry forest and that these specializations tend to follow evolutionary lineages. Tree species common in young forests are more closely related than expected by chance. Tree species that are generalists (similar relative abundance in young and old forests) contribute to convergence in species composition during forest regrowth, whereas rare species and old-forest specialists are sources of divergence.

Our research has important broader impacts. The long-term measurements in our study areas encompassing dozens of study plots emphasize the importance of regrowing tropical forests for conservation and restoration of forests in Latin America.  In addition to the gradual accumulation of native tree species and their associated fauna over time, these rapidly regrowing forests offer a high potential for carbon storage and can play a major role in climate mitigation strategies for Latin American countries. Harnessing the high potential for natural regeneration in favorable areas can increase the cost-effectiveness of large-scale restoration efforts. Our studies have been widely publicized in the press and are broadening the way restoration interventions are being planned and implemented across Latin America.
